resources.string: Device does not support deleting assist data.
Enable logging for NMEA, raw measurements, navigation messages, and more in Settings
Something went wrong with file logging. Did you allow file/storage permissions? Try re-enabling a file logging option in Settings and tap "Allow" when prompted.
Try sharing your location after getting a GNSS fix
Device does not support injecting time data.
Device does not support injecting PSDS data.
Please check system settings - device doesn\'t seem to support GNSS/GPS.
The Map tab requires Google Maps
GPS/GNSS is disabled. Enable it now?
Started GNSS with interval = %1$ss, min. dist. = %2$sm
Some devices may take 24 hours to auto-refresh assist data. If your device doesn\'t support manual injection, GNSS may not work for any app until the auto-refresh completes. Are you sure?
Import a ground truth location using a QR Code in the Geo URI format (geo:28.38434,-87.24334). Create your own QR Codes at https://zxing.appspot.com/generator/.
Couldn\'t read a Geo URI from the QR code
Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) satellites not available
Satellite-based Augmentation System (SBAS) satellites not available

The device GNSS time of:

%1$s

…is more than %2$d days different from your system clock. This can be caused by the GPS week rollover issue - ask your device manufacturer for details. See http://bit.ly/gps-week-rollover for more info.
Tap on map or type your real location
Latitude must be in decimal degrees between -90 and 90
Longitude must be in decimal degrees between -180 and 180
Altitude must be in WGS84 in meters
The imported ground truth location is invalid
GNSS provider or Location is disabled, no updates until it\'s enabled
Device does not support tracking of GNSS Navigation Messages
GNSS Navigation Messages are successfully being tracked
GNSS provider or Location is disabled, no updates until it\'s enabled
Device does not support tracking of GNSS Measurements
GNSS Measurements are successfully being tracked
GPSTest needs access to your location to show GNSS data. If you select \"Never ask again\" you will need to reinstall the app or enable permissions via system settings.
Complaints, kudos, or bug reports are welcome!
Unable to send feedback: no suitable application found.

•  Filter satellites on Status screen - Hide a GNSS using the button on the action bar.
•  GNSS lock indicator - A progress bar is shown while waiting for a GNSS fix, and a lock icon is shown when a position is acquired.
•  Improved dark mode - Map and Sky are now themed.
•  Added Basque translation - Thanks Alexander Gabilondo!
•  Improved launcher icon - Support for adaptive icons on supported devices.
•  Bug fixes - See https://bit.ly/gpstest-releases
Sets the type of map tiles shown
Change the map orientation based on your direction
Change to a first-person map view when you hold up the device
Start GNSS when the app starts
Time between GNSS fixes, in seconds
Available on Android 7.0 and higher. If unchecked, will use the legacy GPSStatus.Listener.
Minimum distance between GNSS fixes, in meters
Enter a min. distance, in meters
Min. Distance must be a number
If enabled will always stop GNSS when the app is put into the background (for example, when using the Home button or Multitasking button to switch apps)
Prevents the screen from turning off
Compass will face true north instead of magnetic north
Log NMEA, raw measurements, or navigation messsages to files or Android Studio
Logs NMEA sentences to Android Studio
Logs GNSS measurements to Android Studio (Android 7.0 and up)
Logs GNSS navigation messages to Android Studio (Android 7.0 and up)
Logs NMEA sentences to a file
Logs GNSS measurements to a file (Android 7.0 and up)
Logs GNSS navigation messages to a file (Android 7.0 and up)
Logs location fix details to a file
Unable to close all file streams.
Shows instructions for using the app
Give the background a dark color and text a light color
Display in decimal degrees, DMS, or degrees decimal minutes
Manually sets the language shown in the app

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) - https://github.com/barbeau/gpstest/blob/master/FAQ.md


*** Status View ***

•  Latitude - In decimal degrees (WGS 84)
•  Longitude - In decimal degrees (WGS 84)
•  Alt - Meters above the WGS 84 ellipsoid
•  Alt (MSL) - Meters above Mean Sea Level (requires NMEA support)
•  E H Acc - Estimated horizontal accuracy of the location (radius in meters of 68% confidence). In other words, if you draw a circle centered at this location's latitude and longitude, and with a radius equal to the accuracy, then there is a 68% probability that the true location is inside the circle. For details see https://medium.com/@sjbarbeau/measuring-gnss-accuracy-on-android-devices-6824492a1389.
•  E H/V Acc - Estimated horizontal and vertical accuracy of the location, both at the 68% confidence. Horizontal accuracy is defined the same as Acc field above. Vertical accuracy is available on Android 8.0 Oreo and higher. Vertical accuracy example - if Alt is 150, and V Acc is 20 then there is a 68% probability of the true altitude being between 130 and 170 meters. For details see https://medium.com/@sjbarbeau/measuring-gnss-accuracy-on-android-devices-6824492a1389.
•  Speed - Speed, in meters/second over ground
•  S. Acc - Estimated speed accuracy of this location at 68% confidence, in meters per second. For example, if Speed is 5, and Speed Acc is 1, then there is a 68% probability of the true speed being between 4 and 6 meters per second.
•  Bearing - The horizontal direction of travel of the device (in degrees 0-360), and is not related to the device orientation.
•  B. Acc - Estimated bearing accuracy of this location at 68% confidence, in degrees. For example, if Bearing is 60, and Bearing Acc is 10, then there is a 68% probability of the true bearing being between 50 and 70 degrees.
•  # Sats - # satellites used in fix / # satellites in view (with valid signal strength values) / # satellites known to device. On dual-frequency devices, a satellite is shown as used if at least one frequency from that satellite is in use, a satellite is shown as in view if at least one signal has a valid signal strength value, and is shown as known to device if there is information about at least one signal from the satellite.
•  PDOP - Position (3D) dilution of precision (requires NMEA support)
•  H/V DOP - Horizontal / vertical dilution of precision (requires NMEA support)
•  TTFF - Time to first fix
•  ID or PRN - identifier of this satellite (pseudorandom noise for GPS)
•  CF - Label (e.g., "L1") for carrier frequency of signal being tracked. If an unknown frequency, it shows the raw frequency in MHz (available on Android 8.0+, but not supported on all devices). The new GLONASS CDMA signal for L1 is shown as "L1-C".
•  SNR - Signal-to-noise ratio (Android M and lower) (https://bit.ly/SNR-CN0)
•  C/N0 - Carrier-to-noise density (Android N and higher) (https://bit.ly/SNR-CN0)
•  Flags - (E) if the device has ephemeris data for the satellite, (A) if the device has almanac data for the satellite, (U) if the satellite was used in calculation of the most recent position fix. For SBAS, the Android spec does not specify if (U) refers to pseudoranges from the satellite being used in the position solution or to correction information originating from that satellite being used.


Inject PSDS data - Requests that the device refresh it's Predicted Satellite Data Service (e.g., XTRA data), if PSDS data is used by the device.


*** Sky View ***

•  GPS (USA Navstar) - Circles
•  GLONASS (Russia) - Squares
•  Galileo (European Union) - Triangles
•  QZSS (Japan) - Hexagons
•  BeiDou/COMPASS (China) - Pentagons
•  IRNSS/NavIC (India) - Ovals
•  SBAS (WAAS, EGNOS, GAGAN, MSAS, SDCM, BDSBAS/SNAS, SACCSA) - Diamonds


•  Transparent satellites - Not in view
 •  Thin outline - In view but not used in fix
 •  Bold outline - Used in fix


•  Expected SNR range is 0 dB (red) to 30 dB (green) on Android versions less than 7.0. 
 •  Expected SNR range is 10 dB (red) to 45 dB (green) on Android 7.0 and higher. 
 •  Expected C/N0 range is 10 dB-Hz (red) to 45 dB-Hz (green) on Android 7.0 and higher. 
 •  If there is no SNR or C/N0 value for a satellite (i.e., it is not in view of the device), it will have a transparent light gray color. 


*** Accuracy View ***

•  Vertical error - Vertical error measurements, unlike horizontal error, can be positive or negative. When displayed in the Accuracy view, vertical error, and average vertical error, are both calculated using the absolute value of the error measurement.


• Set your real location quickly using QR codes. See http://bit.ly/gpstest-qr-codes for details.


*** File Logging ***

 • Enable file logging in Settings for NMEA, raw measurments, nav messages, and location fixes. See http://bit.ly/gpstest-file for details.


*** Acknowledgments ***

 •  Mike Lockwood - original developer for v1.x
 •  Sean Barbeau - developer for v2.x and higher
 •  GPSTest launcher icon is derived from the Android Material Design "satellite" icon, licensed by Google under Apache v2.0. Other Google material design icons are also used under Apache v2.0. QR code icon by Austin Andrews from https://materialdesignicons.com/icon/qrcode.
